It is a most profound experience.
Whether choral or instrumental, Bach enriches the spirit with power.

In truth there is no love in the universe which is not ultimately the
love of God, of the Sacred, and no beauty which is not the reflection of
Divine Beauty. Even a person who thinks that he is an atheist, when he
says, ‘‘I am an atheist, and I do not believe in anything,’’ he has actually
transferred his religious love and devotion to something else other than
formal religion, but the search for love and beauty still exists in him
even if he is unaware of their transcendent Source. When such a person,
if he is sensitive to music, listens to Johann Sebastian Bach or Mozart,
he wants everything to be very quiet, concentrating completely with his
whole soul in a state of devotion. In fact what he is doing is searching
for the Sacred in this beautiful music, but he is not aware of the real
source of this attraction for his soul. What is it that is attracting him to
Bach or Mozart ‘‘religiously’’? Why is he so much interested in this
musical experience? Where does this state in his mind and soul come
from? Often he is not aware enough to really sit down and seek to
discover what the source of this ‘‘feeling’’ is.
(Seyyed Hossein Nasr)

I learned to appreciate all forms and styles of music, but classical was the foundation upon which all was based. Music can add peace and joy beyond measure to one's life.

GLORIA SEI DIR GESUNGEN, BWV 140 Nr, 7
(Philipp Nicolai) Bach-Geſellſchaft, GeMA

It's true that Mozart and Beethoven studied Bach, and applied his influence in their late works. However, we can attribute much of Bach's modern popularity to Mendelssohn, who conducted concerts of Bach's music and started a Bach revival movement.

Bach was born in 1685. During his lifetime, his music was not nearly as popular or revered as it is today. Unlike the cosmopolitan and internationally celebrated Handel, Bach did not travel through Europe. He stayed in Germany, mostly working church jobs. His later work was seen as old-fashioned, not nearly fashionable, and cutting-edge "galant" composers like Hasse were held in higher regard.
